posts.cooked:
Hello Everyone!

We have a lot of things in development that I'm sure will surprise and interest many of you, but before releasing everything, I need to plan out the changes you'd love to see in YAGSL. I know we've had some setbacks this year, and we've discussed all our options to ensure these issues never happen again!

Here's our current plan for YAGSL to significantly improve everything from delivery to utilization next year:

1. Monorepo:
   - YAGSL will follow GitHub Actions' lead by centralizing repositories into 1 with GitHub Actions controlling releases.

More examples:
- We're switching from one giant example to multiple new ones based on the current system. These include:
  * SwerveDrive with a drive-forward autonomous
  * SwerveDrive with drive-forward and vision using PhotonVision
  * SwerveDrive with drive-forward and vision using Limelight
  * SwerveDrive using PathPlanner
  * SwerveDrive using Pathfinder
  * SwerveDrive field-oriented with drive-forward autonomous
  * SwerveDrive field-oriented with PathPlanner
  * SwerveDrive field-oriented with PathPlanner and Vision

Updated documentation:
- We'll fix last year's Shuffleboard documentation and switch all references to Elastic documentation.

In-code configuration:
- In-code configs are possible but ugly. We'll replace helper functions in SwerveDrive and SwerveModule with a configuration class.

Configuration classes:
- SwerveDrive and SwerveModule will extend a class modifying the config class. We'll add depreciation notices while introducing new configuration classes.

Web configurator update:
- Improve the existing web configurator to be more user-friendly with warnings and better hints.

Dynamic vendordep importing:
- Testing is live, aiming to dynamically load vendordeps so users only install what they need.

Better brushed motor support:
- Improve support for external encoders on brushed motors, allowing teams to swap setups as needed.

Configuration app:
- Development is ongoing, though not yet released this season.

Other improvements:
- Considering gear ratios for absolute encoders and aliases for common configurations.

Please share any feedback or suggestions!

posts.name: elijah lipscomb
posts.cooked: Images to go along with PID tuning would be nice. Watching a 1-hour tutorial on it was painful.

Images for PID tuning are challenging and may not effectively convey the concept compared to browser tuner examples found in the WPILib documentation, which could serve as a complete alternative if desired. Additionally, the PID tuning table in the documentation offers a quick way to grasp the fundamentals.

link_counts.title: Tuning a Turret Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
From a CSA perspective... there was a critical issue where the robot didn’t restart if using REV devices and it crashed in a match while connected to the FMS. There was a fix available, but not published when I CSA’ed at a Week 4 event. I only knew about it from watching CSA’s Slack. By my next event, Week 6, the fix was showing as available in the vendor deps VS Code plugin, but still wouldn’t update (the old Manage Vendor Libraries worked).

I saw this impact 3 teams Week 4, and 2 teams Week 6. It’s sad to see a team whose robot was dead on the field during a match.

TL;DR; Consider finding a way to get critical fixes published faster. Consider ways for CSA’s to help teams update without an internet connection.

This is a tough problem. I am able to publish via the old way and have it available instantly but currently lack automation to deploy a PR to GitHub - wpilibsuite/vendor-json-repo, which the vendordep plugin uses. Even if I did, it would take several minutes to hours for a WPILib maintainer to merge it in. Additionally, I must differentiate between beta and full releases. To resolve this, I plan to obtain more CD abbreviations to enable automatic PR posting to vendordep-json-repo. Thank you for your assistance!

link_counts.title: GitHub - wpilibsuite/vendor-json-repo: WPILib Vendor JSON Repository

posts.name: Michael Hill
posts.cooked: The current system of having one GIANT example for the most complex robot is too difficult to navigate or understand for most new teams. We are switching to creating several new examples based on the current one. While I found the giant example as a PERFECT skeleton for our team’s code, especially during my first year with Swerve and Java, having nearly complete code saved us a lot of time and effort. It provided a clear starting point and helped me learn how to incorporate features like vision pose updates with Photonvision.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: It almost looks like that kind of example will still exist as one of the options. The change is that there will also be some simpler options. Correct me if I’m wrong.

posts.name: Michael Hill
posts.cooked: SwerveDrive field-oriented and PathPlanner with PhotonVision for global pose

posts.name: kieran
posts.cooked: It made it so much easier for our team to get started this year. I think splitting it is the right move though. More examples is always better!

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Our team was extremely impressed with YAGSL, a Yet Another Generic Swerve Library. One thing we love is the deployed json configuration tooling, as it allows us to run the same code on both our 4-module standard bot and a 2-module testbench bot. Furthermore, any new YAGSL project receives a fully tuned drive right out of the gate, making it an excellent setup for newcomers.

Despite its many benefits, we encountered two significant issues during our experience with YAGSL:

1. Unexpected and unclear documentation about handling switching fieldcentric driver input between red and blue sides led to messy code despite our eventual success.

2. Random disconnections of Navx2 running in SPI mode during matches caused gyro resets, costing us several autos and matches until we resolved it by switching to USB mode. Documenting such quirks would greatly improve discoverability and prevent future issues.

3. Additionally, we faced challenges in recovering JSON configuration files from the remote deploy folder, which occasionally required accessing these files due to unforeseen Unix work. This added complexity highlighted the importance of adequate mentorship for newer programmers.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Better brushed motor support has been significantly improved to allow for external encoders on azimuth/steering/angle motors. This means teams won't need to rely on specific setups for brushed motor compatibility on modules and can swap them out as needed. Having implemented a swerve with talons this year, this is the number one thing I'm excited for.

posts.name: Sisters 1st
posts.cooked:
Extremely important - do not output anything but the cleaned version (no introduction, no other little explanation), just the cleaned paragraph.

Mostly at random every few matches, our NavX2 running in SPI mode would disconnect the moment auto started, which was eventually traced back to some YAGSL interaction forcing a gyro reset. This cost us multiple autos (and a couple matches) before we could sort it out and use USB mode and resolve the issues. Documenting such quirks on the site (and preferably, the configuration tool) would help a lot for discoverability and avoiding odd hardware combinations. We only found this buried in a chief delphi post after effectively pinning down the issue and specifically searching for it to confirm the fault.

Us and FRC3142 saw the same things this year. Very frustrating until we switched to USB. Besides this, YAGSL was flawless this year.

You guys were definitely not the only ones frustrated about that. I try to catch things ahead of time and even had a team near me who uses a NavX this year. I was relying on them to let me know of anything like this during the beta (November-Jan) and nothing like this came up. I will try my best to make sure this doesn’t happen again!

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: I talked to a team from outside the US that wanted to use YAGSL, but didn’t because it didn’t support metric units.

That was a concern, which I dismissed because teams could plug it into Google with "What is Xmeters in inches" and then copy and paste the calculation. Now, they can also use the Windows calculator for this purpose.

posts.name: jwhite
posts.cooked:
I interacted only peripherally with YAGSL, as a CSA helping teams work with it. First, it seems to be an incredible tool that allowed teams to get going quickly; mad props are in order. What I’ve been telling my fellow mentors, though, is that it feels like its development speed has created some rough edges. The example of the critical update which you had to manually apply is a good example. Another was when I was working with a YAGSL expert to help a team, and he was concerned that they had used an ‘old’ template to generate their code and that meant they were missing features.

The constructive advice I would offer is to increase the priority of stability. That is, it’s more valuable to be reliable and predictable than to have the more features. Or to have some very clear versioning; so when I go the web site, it says: “Make sure you only use YAGSL 17.9 Blue compatible templates.” Or make sure that when you google “YAGSL example code” the results don’t horrify you.

posts.name: Johnny Dreher
posts.cooked: We are experiencing odometry issues. Over distances exceeding 1 meter—approximately 4 feet—we’re from Brazil and use the metric system—the odometry begins to lose accuracy, with errors approaching nearly 5%. This figure isn’t something we find acceptable, especially for high-precision tasks where better accuracy is needed. Could you provide more advanced guidance on improving calibration effectively? We greatly admire YAGSL, Yet Another Generic Swerve Library, and although we attempted to develop our own solution, we’ve since decided against it.

When odometry becomes unreliable, several potential issues may arise. Wheels could be worn such that their actual diameter differs from the pre-calculated value. Additionally, the diameter measurement might exclude the tread portion, leading to inaccuracies. Another possibility is inadequate lubrication of the gears, which can cause them to wear out prematurely. Incorrect gear ratios could also contribute to the problem, especially when attempting to calculate the ratio manually rather than using established methods. Furthermore, using faulty hardware components—such as relying on an ADIS or NavX sensor—which can introduce unpredictable gyroscope drift, requires careful tuning or alternative solutions. Lastly, poorly calibrated PID control loops may exacerbate the issue, making troubleshooting more challenging.

posts.name: Johnny Dreher
posts.cooked: We will try all this. Something like real diameters and greased gears we already do it.

posts.name: Johnny Dreher
posts.cooked:
The assistant's response:  
We have implemented all this and are now more accurate. We achieve 1.5% error rate at 6 meters. At 3 meters, our error drops below 1%.
